qas.question: During which revolution was red a symbol of liberty?
What kind of cap did the Jacobins wear?

answers.text: red Phrygian cap, or liberty cap

qas.question: Women with red caps crowded around guillotines during the Reign of Terror to do what?
During what years did the Reign of Terror take place?

answers.text: Christian martyr and patron saint of Paris

qas.question: What became a symbol of liberty during the Phrygian Revolution?
What did red become a symbol of during the Phrygian Revolution?

plausible_answers.text: Jacobins and other more radical parties

qas.question: Who used red as a symbol of liberty and personal freedom during the Phrygian Revolution?
When did the Terror Reign take place?
What colors did France go back to during the Reign of Terror?

context: During the <a0_0>French Revolution<a0_0/>, <b5_0>Red<b5_0/> became a symbol of <b6_0>liberty and personal freedom<b6_0/> used by the <b7_0>Jacobins and other more radical parties<b7_0/>. Many of them wore a <a1_0>red Phrygian cap, or liberty cap<a1_0/>, modeled after the caps worn by freed slaves in Ancient Rome. During the height of the Reign of Terror, Women wearing red caps gathered around the guillotine to <a2_0>celebrate<a2_0/> each execution. They were called the "Furies of the guillotine". The guillotines used during the Reign of Terror in <a3_0><b8_0>1792 and 1793<b8_0/><a3_0/> were painted red, or made of red wood. During the Reign of Terror a statue of a woman titled liberty, painted red, was placed in the square in front of the guillotine. After the end of the Reign of Terror, France went back to the <b9_0>blue, white and red tricolor,<b9_0/> whose red was taken from the traditional color of Saint Denis, the <a4_0>Christian martyr and patron saint of Paris<a4_0/>.
